text: I wanted to talk with you today about a phenomenon that some people experience on their spiritual path, and that's the phenomenon of visions and hallucinations. Just to talk in a general sense about what to do with that kind of phenomenon and a sort of overview of where that fits in spiritual growth. As I'm sure you're all aware, there are many models or paradigms that we can use to describe the process of a person's spiritual growth. And one of them that I'd like to share with you, it's just one out of many possible ways of looking at it, is that we can talk about a path that is a journey from surface consciousness to the source of consciousness. And in traversing this path from surface to source, we pass through intermediate realms. Now what do I mean by surface consciousness? Surface consciousness is what we might call ordinary consensual consciousness. There's a separation. I'm over here, I've got my car over there, I've got to get on the freeway and negotiate to get here, etc., etc. This is the ordinary world that we function in much of the time. What do I mean by the source? Well the source is actually not a thing. The source is an activity. It's a process. But we can, for simplicity's sake, consider it if you have the surface of consciousness here, the source of consciousness would be deep, deep down. So we can talk about bringing qualities of clarity. Instead of just looking across the surface of consciousness, we turn 90 degrees and begin to infuse clarity down into the substance of consciousness. And in doing that, we are sort of clarifying the intermediate realms between the surface and this activity of the source. So from this model or this perspective, we can talk about three layers, although that's actually somewhat misleading because the source isn't a layer. It's a movement rather than a thing. But for simplicity's sake, you can consider three layers. Surface or ordinary consensual experience, the source, and then that which is in between, the intermediate layers. In terms of traditional Buddhist vocabulary, the surface is called the nirmanakaya. Kaya means body and nirmana means appearance, ordinary appearance. The source is called dharmakaya, which means the body of the absolute, you might say. And the intermediate realms are referred to as the sambhogakaya. Now sambhoga is a word that we don't exactly have an English equivalent for, but I guess if we had to find one, it would be archetype in the Jungian sense of the word archetype. The intermediate realms, the intermediate experience is both the dwelling place of our problems, our blockages, our impurities, the things that prevent the surface from touching the source moment by moment. But the intermediate realm is also a realm of special powers and unusual experiences. Sambhoga actually in Sanskrit means like glory. Some people, as they're in this process of going from surface to source, encounter various manifestations in those intermediate realms. Special situations that can bring about those kinds of manifestations are sensory deprivation, physical extremes like going without sleep, hunger, thirst, extreme cold, extreme heat, physical pain can thrust one into those realms, as well as of course various substances that people take. In those intermediate realms, we can have actual experiences of encountering the archetypes. Now in the Jungian sense of archetypes, archetypes are manifestations. They could be manifestations of our impurities. You can have things that come up for you that are very fearful. You can see monsters, you can see ghosts, you can see terrifying manifestations. Or you can see things that are very seductive, erotic, sexual. In fact the very avatar, the very embodiment of fear and lust can appear. Those are archetypes in the sense of manifestations of our impurities, our blockages. And people see the most incredible things sometimes. They see totally demonic things, demonic, even demonic ceremonies going on or very violent acts or you see skeletons or all sorts of weird stuff. Or an image can come up for a person that is like the absolutely perfect sexual object for you, tailor made by the universe that you could never find in the physical world ever. Okay. The girl or man or whatever fetish of your dreams, whatever it may be, that can never actually exist can appear for you before your very eyes. Of course the embodiments that happen in those realms are not just embodiments of the impurities of consciousness, our craving and aversions, but can be embodiments of positive aspects of consciousness. You can encounter sages and saints and the positive spiritual archetypes. That's why that realm is referred to as the Sambhogakaya. In the positive sense one can see bodies of glory, beautiful bodhisattvas, buddhas, whatever gods, goddesses, entities that can communicate with you, share things with you, help you in the parlance of Native North America spirits. Those intermediate realms can be quite interesting or they can be quite frightening. What to make of these experiences? In the title of today's talk I said using visions and hallucinations. Vision sounds positive and in fact the Native North Americans talk about going on a vision quest. Hallucination sounds negative and false. What's the difference between a vision and a hallucination? I would suggest to you that the difference between a vision and a hallucination is what one makes of it. And it's not in my purview to comment on the ontological reality of these things. In other words, do they really exist or not exist? That to me is sort of a mute point. The important thing is some people experience it and therefore it is a phenomenon that comes up and needs to be understood and dealt with. I know that the burning issue for a lot of people is, you know, is there an objective spirit world? Are these archetypes objectively real? But that's something that I don't really address. That's not an issue for me. The issue is how does one relate to it in terms of really getting spiritual growth? And what I'd like to suggest to you is that there are three ways of relating to the visions and hallucinations that a person may have. One way is that you can become interested in the content. By that I mean, let's say that you give a positive vision, an entity, a spirit, a bodhisattva appears in front of you and blesses you and you feel like energy and light coming from this being and it's blessing you and purifying you. Or maybe they'll speak words and those are words of wisdom. So there's a positive content there and some people use that as a spiritual guidance. By the way, I should mention, even though we use the word vision, I just want to add something parenthetically that I left out. These manifestations can take place in any of the six consciousnesses. According to the Buddhist theory of consciousness, there are six sense doors, hearing, seeing, smelling, tasting, the touch sense or the feeling body, and the thinking mind. These are the six ways that consciousness manifests. And although one often sees, and I guess that's why it's called vision or visionary material, one can also hear, but one can also feel, actual touch and smell and taste. It can happen in any or all of the sense gates. I remember I once actually had an experience of, this was many, many years ago, it was auditory, tactile and visual at the same time. I had a hallucination that there was a little man tap dancing on my hand. And not only could I hear his drum and see him quite vividly, but I could feel his little feet touching. So there was a tactile component there. So so-called visions or so-called hallucinations can take place in any of the sense realms and in all of them. As I said, there are three ways that we can relate to this material. One of them is in terms of content. If the visions and hallucinations are on the positive side, if we're seeing saints and sages and ancestors and spirits, people get information from this that may be useful for them, inner guide type experiences. Of course, if the visions and hallucinations are negative and we relate to it in terms of its content, that means we get freaked out. If they happen to be erotic and embodiments of our cravings, we get sucked in. And it's sort of like glorified sexual fantasy, but really it's like sexual fantasy to the max because it's like absolutely perfect and real. That's getting sucked into the content of negative stuff. Or if it's terrifying, frightening, bizarre, then we get freaked out. Hopefully, a person will understand that in addition to being involved in the content of what's manifesting, there are two other important things, ways to relate to visionary or hallucinatory material. Regardless of what the source is, whatever is causing it, be it drugs, be it sensory deprivation, be it extreme pain, be it fever or illness, it makes no difference, whatever causes it. The two other ways of relating are in terms of purification and insight. I guess I would rather say deep purification and deep insight. As I mentioned, there are many models, many paradigms, many ways of describing how the spiritual path works. And one of the ones that I like the most is the one that's used in vipassana, the vipassana form of meditation. And in this model, one relates to experience, any experience, with two qualities. One of the qualities is called mindfulness, which means a kind of precision moment by moment about what's going on. A second quality is called equanimity, which means literally in Latin, equanimous, means a balanced consciousness. But in this case it means an attitude of a witness state where there's not a pushing away or a grabbing on. Whenever one brings the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity to an experience, whether that experience is intense or banal, whether it's ordinary or extraordinary, two things are happening. There is a process of insight and a process of purification. What do we mean by purification? Well, let's talk about what we mean by the opposite of purification. The opposite of purification is, quote, impurity. I always like to put the word impurity in quotes because the impurities are things like craving and aversion, but also the negative tapes, the negative conditionings, the internal conflicts. You can use a lot of models for talking about the impurities. You can use a psychological model. We're talking about complexes. We're talking about negative conditionings that a person has gone through. We're talking about the tendency to inner conflict at all the different layers, including a microscopic moment by moment, teeny frictions that arise in each of the six senses. That's one way to look at the impurities. Another way to look at the impurities is more of a theological model. It's what in the West is called sinfulness, that which separates us from God. Or another way to look at the impurities is that it is our moment by moment tendency to congeal the flow of nature and freeze it into a thing called the self and a thing called the world. There's lots of ways to look at the so-called impurities. The Buddhist parlance, the impurities, come under three basic categories. Craving, which is the congealing or holding around the flow of pleasure, and the drive to repeat pleasure, as opposed to simply the full experience of pleasure. Aversion, which is the resistance to physical and psychological discomfort. And then unconsciousness, ignorance, just not being aware moment by moment, or being subject to processes that one is not aware of. These are the three, big three, raga, dvesha, moha, the craving, the aversion, and the unconsciousness. In any event, whenever one takes any aspect of experience, something as ordinary as your clothes touching your body, something as ordinary as driving your car, or something as extraordinary as monsters or saints appearing before your very eyes, whenever one takes any experience and brings the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity to that experience, then insight and purification is taking place. In other words, blockages are being released and understandings are being fostered. Now the kinds of understandings that we're talking about are deep understandings. What do we mean by deep understandings? Understandings about the fundamental issues. In science they talk about fundamental research. Fundamental research is hard, it takes a lot of energy, it takes a lot of time, it's expensive. But when you get answers from fundamental research, thousands and thousands of specific applications come out of one fundamental theoretical breakthrough. In the same way, the thousands and thousands of solutions to life situations will arise for you if you get one major breakthrough in terms of the fundamental issues. What are fundamental issues? Everybody in this room has a sense of self, don't you? Don't you? I certainly do. I'm quite self-conscious as I'm sitting here. If I were to start to point you out and mention your name and say things about you in front of the group that we're either praising or condemning, wouldn't you have a rising of a sense of self-consciousness? We all have a sense of self. Can you tell me something that's true and useful about that sense of self? Fundamental insights would be things that are true and useful about how a person's sense of self arises, where it comes from, what its nature is, and what is the relationship between having a sense of an individual self and letting go of that identity and sharing in larger identities or smaller identities. What the heck do I mean by that? Well maybe when you hear the sound of the horn out there, that's an identity that's somewhat smaller than a human identity, isn't it? Can you share in that identity and how can you do that? How about the experience of this whole room here? Or how about the experience of the whole universe? Or the experience of another human being? That's an experience that seems larger than an individual identity. How can we share in that? What's the relationship between our ordinary identity and the breaking of that ordinary identity and experiencing other identities as ourself? Can we have that experience? And if we can, why do we have that experience? What brings that about? Individual understandings would allow us to understand something about our own individuality, but also understand something about how to experience oneness with things. How important is it to become free from suffering? It's not a trick question. How important is it? Well you get the answer to that one the next time you suffer, either physically or psychologically in any little way. Correct? You'll get the answer to that, how important it is. It's more important than anything at that time. Whatever a person's life may have been, once they start physically or emotionally suffering, it doesn't mean beans. There's only one thing that means anything at all, which is in that moment to be able to be free from that suffering. But what if the suffering arises from circumstances that can't be changed no matter what? Is there still a way to be free? Is there still a way to be okay? Yeah, there is. And to understand that, to understand that with crystal clarity is a very important insight. So this is what we might call fundamental insight. How about the experience of pleasure? Usually pleasure doesn't bring permanent transformation. All over the world in every culture, not in every culture, but in many, many cultures, people are uneasy about sex. It's the most intense pleasure. Why are we uneasy about it? Why do we look upon it as dirty? This may be a shocking answer to some people, may be very off-putting, so please listen carefully to what I'm going to say. The reason people look upon sex as dirty is because it is, for most people, very dirty. There's nothing dirty about pleasure, of course. Just like the stronger the pain, the more we resist it, and therefore the bigger the suffering it turns into, the stronger the pleasure, the more we grasp onto it, and therefore prevent it from really transforming consciousness. So what happens is that most intense pleasure, which is the sexual pleasure, gets surrounded by so much holding and craving that its promise is never realized. The promise, of course, is the promise of real satisfaction, lasting fulfillment, transformative satisfaction, the kind of satisfaction that transforms consciousness permanently. That's the prospect that is held out, that is almost never realized, because of the inability to have a complete experience of pleasure. Understanding that pleasure plus equanimity yields lasting satisfaction, and understanding that pain plus equanimity frees one from suffering, to really understand that, to really see that directly, not just believe it, but to have experience of it at every level of one's being, down to the microscopic flow of the nerves themselves. This is fundamental insight. So pleasure is important, pain is important, self is important, oneness is important, separateness are important, important to understand. Just as there are many facets to purification, there are many facets to insight also. Whenever one takes any aspect of experience, from the extraordinary to the banal, from the mild to the most intense, and brings the qualities of precision and openness, that is to say mindfulness and equanimity, one is fostering this process of releasing the blockages and clarifying one's spiritual insight. But different aspects of experience bring purification and insight in different ways. And the case in point is the aspect of experience called visions and hallucinations. If a person is able to bring the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity while they're having visionary or hallucinatory experiences, then they reach very, very deep down into consciousness, and purify and get insight in very, very deep ways. In the Zen tradition, the visions and hallucinations that happen to some people in their practice are often referred to as makyo, M-A-K-Y-O. Now that's an interesting word in the Japanese language. Ma actually comes originally from Sanskrit. It's an abbreviation of the Sanskrit word Mara. And Mara means, does anybody know what Mara means in Sanskrit? The devil? The devil, yeah. Mara is the Buddhist devil. Literally, it's the same root as the English root mortal. It's the killer. The adversary, Diabolos, Satan, is Mara. And then in Japanese, it gets abbreviated to Ma. And kyo is another very interesting word in Japanese, because it means, literally it means where you live, both in the subjective and objective sense. Kyo is the scene, I guess if I had to translate it into English. And it refers both to your internal scene, in other words, your state of consciousness, and your external scene, where you're abiding. Your abode is kyo. So makyo literally means the abode of the devil, if we were to literally translate it into English. So it's obviously a pejorative term, a put-down term. But on the other hand, Zen masters often are happy when their students start to experience makyo, because they take it as a sign that the meditation is deepening. You're going from the surface realm, and you're now in these intermediate power realms, where you're getting these weird experiences. Not everybody has hallucinatory and visionary experiences on the spiritual path. Some people clarify the realms between surface and source without ever having these experiences at all. But other people have these experiences. Why do they put it down? Why do they call it makyo, saying that's the realm of the devil? Because people have a strong tendency to get involved in the content of that experience and not simply observe it with mindfulness and equanimity. As I say, if your visionary material is positive, if you've got spirits and saints in front of you, getting involved in the content of that can be helpful sometimes to your practice. If they're giving you blessings and good energy and helping you along on your path. But getting involved in the content, even if it's positive content, even if you've got an inner guide that's giving you good advice, is still not going to let you realize the full potential of that experience. And the reason that they put it down and they say this is makyo, ma means the devil, but actually devil in the Buddhist tradition means something that blocks or gets in the way of deeper progress. When a person is having visionary or hallucinatory material, they are at a crossroads, you might say. They can go one of two ways. Either you get caught up in the content of that material. If it's positive content, spiritual content, well, that's not so bad, but you're still caught up in the content of it. If it's negative content, you're going to get involved in, you're going to reinforce the impurities. But in either event, if one is involved in the content of one's visions or hallucinations, one is missing a fantastic opportunity, because when you get visionary and hallucinatory material, it's a sign that you're in the intermediate realms between surface and source. It's a signpost that you're going towards the source. And if you're able to maintain mindfulness and equanimity with respect to that material, you can very quickly plummet the source and get insight and purification. But what happens is, do you all know what a self-limiting mechanism is? A self-limiting device, that thermostat over there is a perfect example of a self-limiting device. You turn on the heat, the room gets hotter and hotter and hotter, but as the room heats, it moves the spring inside that thermostat. And at a certain point, that spring has moved enough and the heat turns itself off, and the room doesn't heat up anymore. Otherwise the room would heat infinitely. One of the greatest dangers on the spiritual path is that the spiritual path itself becomes a self-limiting mechanism. It's got built into itself something that stops its own progress. So you start to plummet from surface to source, and this intermediate material arises. And you get involved in the content of that intermediate material, and now you've turned 90 degrees. You're not plummeting straight down anymore. You turn 90 degrees, you're now exploring out horizontally. And it's become a self-limiting mechanism because the component of motion towards the source has been eliminated. And of course there are three extremes and a whole bunch of in-between possibilities. One extreme is you start to plummet, you encounter that material, and it's weird or frightening or enticing, and you say, I don't want to have anything to do with this, this ain't for me. Okay, this is makyo, this is the realm of the devil, and I can't handle it. So you pop right back up on the surface and you say, I ain't going down into consciousness anymore. That's one extreme reaction. A lot of people have that, typically a fear reaction. I can't handle this, this is too weird. And you've gone halfway down and you get into that and you pop back up and you say, I want to stay up here on the surface where I can breathe the air I'm used to. That's one extreme reaction. A second extreme reaction is you get 100% involved in content. You turn 90 degrees and it's now either you're pursuing the hallucinations as embodiments of craving and aversion, or you're pursuing the hallucinations and visions as embodiments of a kind of intermediate spiritual wisdom, but you're still pursuing that. A third extreme case is you keep your mindfulness and equanimity and no matter how compelling the visions and hallucinations, you observe them the same way you'd observe your breath or the touch of the clothes on your body, with that matter of fact precision. And then you keep plummeting down, down, down, down, down. The intermediate possibilities are you get somewhat involved in content, but also you maintain some mindfulness and equanimity and you go at an oblique angle. You still have a component of motion towards the source, but you also have a component of motion out. A component of your movement is out exploring the content, the specifics of those visions and hallucinations. That oblique thing, which is in between, you see what I'm talking about in terms of angles, right? You can either go 180 degrees the opposite direction. You can continue your motion straight down. You can turn 90 degrees or you can have these oblique angles. The preferred Buddhist path is straight down. A very common experience is you pop back up on the surface and you don't go down anymore. Another common experience is turn 90 degrees and get involved in content. When you're turned at something between 90 degrees and straight down, this is the religion called shamanism that has both aspects of insight and purification, but also aspects of exploring those realms in terms of the empowerments and the content and whatever. If you are turned 90 degrees and you have no component of insight and purification, you're not going closer to the source, but you're getting more and more interesting, powerful, unusual, or perhaps demonic experiences, then this is the world of, what shall we call it? If it's on the negative side, it would really be called Satanism and that kind of thing. If it's on the positive side, then it might be called spiritualism in the sense of just the spiritual powers and only lip service is being given to real spiritual growth. Then there's a lot of intermediate that goes on, I mean in between angles. In tribal cultures, there's both purification insight, but also they're interested in the content. They want to talk to their ancestors and their spirits. As I say, from the perspective of Buddhist practice, the reason that it's called makyo and put down is that people will have a tendency to turn 90 degrees and get lost in that stuff. But also the reason it's put down is that people lose this incredible opportunity for really deep insight and purification because here's the interesting phenomenon. If visionary or hallucinatory material arises and you're able to maintain equanimity and mindfulness, the visions and hallucinations get more realistic, not less. If you maintain more equanimity and more mindfulness, the visions and hallucinations get even more realistic, not less. Now what do I mean by mindfulness? Let's say that you're sitting and meditating and your patron saint appears in front of you. Or it's like it's happened to me times where a bodhisattva will appear in front of you. What is this experience in terms of consciousness? Well you're seeing something, so that's seeing. You're having mental reactions like, wow, this is pretty weird. That's thinking. And you've got all sorts of body sensations, perhaps fearful, perhaps pleasant, perhaps tensions. Your body's reacting. If you get negative hallucinatory materials, if you see like real sexy images, okay, again you're seeing and your mind's thinking, my God, that is the most incredibly enticing perfect female form. Your mind's thinking, in my case, those are the thoughts that would be arising. And erotic sensation over your whole body. So what's the content of this experience? Okay, seeing, thinking, and feeling. To be able to keep track, that's seeing, that's thinking, and that's feeling in the body, is to have mindfulness. And to watch that come and go is to have equanimity. Now let's take the seeing part. I'm looking out at any of you when I see you. Do I just look straight at you or does my eye sort of wander over your body? Okay. Have you ever noticed your vision's constantly shifting, isn't it? Since you came into this room, how many times did the angle of your vision shift? Thousands. Each one of those was a complete, separate arising of the visual sense. Do you know how large your angle of central vision is? Central vision is the clear vision as opposed to peripheral. How big an angle do you think you can actually see? 30 degrees. It's actually a couple degrees. It's like an incredibly narrow corridor that you can actually see anything clearly. Everything else is very fuzzy. Is that where your attention is concentrated? Yeah. What happens is that the eye is constantly wandering over the visual field, and it patches the image together, and you get the sense that there's this panorama in front, but actually you're just going, ch-ch-ch-ch. Same way if you've ever paid attention to your body sensations, you'll know that the awareness floats around inside your body. And those of you that have meditated paying attention to your body sensations know that as you become aware of how attention is constantly shifting in the body, the sense of the body gets softer and softer, and you start to get a sense that really the body is quite insubstantial, and there's a wave-like rising and fading of sensation. And each one of those waves is made of wavelets, and the wavelets are made up of tiny little vibrations, and so there is like expansion and contraction of feeling, and that's all your body really is. Well, the same is true for the visual sense. So if you're looking at one of these hallucinations or visions, and you're able to be aware each time your eye shifts over it, you see the head, you see the hand, you see, okay, and you're aware of each individual arising and passing of your thought reactions, and you're aware of how your body is welling up and fading in reaction, now you've got even more mindfulness, okay, and you just let that happen, so you have equanimity. Well, what happens is, as you're doing that, amazingly, the visionary material becomes more and more realistic, the more detached you become, until finally it simply becomes real, absolutely real, in the sense that anything is real. In other words, we have a sense that, like, you're looking at a real world here. The visionary or so-called hallucinatory material can become that vivid. And as I say, the really interesting thing is, the more detached you are, the more realistic it becomes, and the more vivid it becomes, until it becomes completely vivid. If you are able to maintain mindfulness and equanimity to the point where it becomes completely real, then you gain tremendous insight into the nature of how consciousness produces appearances. In other words, insight and purification, if you're able to watch this stuff that may be psychologically very charged, charged spiritually, you may see your own patron saint, you may see your own dead parents, they talk to you, or charged in a negative sense, that you see the very embodiments of lust and terror. If you're able to observe that material with an even-minded attitude, then you're purifying consciousness, you're releasing the blockages. But also, if you're able to observe with great precision, you can gain insight into the nature of consciousness itself. What is the process, what is the chain of events whereby the source manifests appearance? In the Hebrew Kabbalistic mystical tradition, they talk about br'ha yesh me'ayin. The entire goal of the mystical endeavor, according to Judaism, is to be able to perceive br'ha yesh me'ayin. It means br'ha, that's the word that in the Old Testament means creation. You know, like in Genesis, br'shid bara. Yesh is something, something could be a bell, a sound of a horn, a human personality, a cat, a tree, an itch. Yesh is something. Me'ayin means from, and ayin means nothing, empty, nothingness. That's of course a very special nothingness. The nothingness of the mystics is a very, very special kind of nothingness. It's translated in English as continuous creation. How it is that the source, which is this kind of very special nothingness, churns things, time, space, self, and world into existence moment by moment. That is one of the deepest aspects, one of the deepest facets of insight. When a person is having so-called visionary or hallucinatory experiences, they're right on the threshold of having that insight. Because what's happening at that time is, this may seem like a very strange way of putting it, but consciousness is dancing its dance in miniature. Right now we're going through a huge, huge visionary experience that's so impactful that it's very hard to realize it's just a visionary experience. We're going through this huge hallucination of being in this room listening to a talk. And it's like the macchio is so big that it's very, very hard to see it as macchio. When you have a visionary experience, you're getting a little miniature version of that. And it's much more manageable, and in a sense much easier to see the action of consciousness. So something appears in front of your eyes, okay? And you get real detached and real opened up, and you are aware that you're looking at that part, you're looking at this part, your body's arising this way, your thoughts are arising this way, you just let that happen. And you let go, and pretty soon what starts to happen is you get this sense that there is a kind of churning motion of consciousness that's expanding and contracting and vibrating at many, many levels simultaneously. And just like when the ocean churns, when the waves of the ocean expand and contract, it churns foam into existence, well in the same way that churning of consciousness, that movement, that flow of impermanence, is literally churning that visionary experience into existence. And the more detached you become, and the more you open up and carefully observe, the more animated that flow of impermanence becomes, and the more realistic the phenomenon that's being churned up becomes, until finally you reach the point where you completely surrender to that flow. I know I've lost half the people in the room right now, you're looking at me like, what in the world is this guy talking about? This is like so far off, okay? But I'll just mention it because some of you will experience it as you continue to meditate. I'll just repeat. You'll get a sense that there is a pure movement or action that is molding that so-called hallucination. And the more you become detached from the hallucination, the more activated that flow becomes and therefore the more realistic it's able, you're giving it permission to make it, basically. You're giving that little piece of consciousness permission to expand and contract any way it wants and churn this experience into existence. So the more detached you become, the more realistic it becomes, until you become completely detached at which point it becomes completely real. And you get an insight into how consciousness creates so-called reality. So the reason that Buddhist teachers are so adamant about how to relate to visions and hallucinations is that people miss an incredible opportunity. It's like, how can I put it, it's like by getting exclusively involved in the content of the vision or hallucination, one misses out on that potential that's there for purification, number one. But even more importantly for the insight into the nature of how consciousness creates all forms, including the ordinary forms of the impression of I'm in a room inside rigid space that always exists and inside that space there are separate objects and there is a separate thing called a self inside of me. That experience, our ordinary experience of the world, the experience of being here now, this is being churned into existence moment by moment, prihayeshme'en, okay? This thingness that we're experiencing is coming about moment by moment from that activity that's called emptiness or nothingness. And when it acts in miniature, so to speak, we get these visions and hallucinations and we can learn from that. And learning from that we can then extrapolate and generalize and realize, oh, the same thing's been going on all my life, okay? I've been living inside, like the Hindus put it, you're living inside Vishnu's dream. I've been living inside this activity. So this is, I feel, the most productive way to relate to visionary and hallucinatory experiences if they should happen to you. That pretty much brings me to the end of what I wanted to say. Everybody's smiling, everybody's laughing. Where did that smile come from? Pay attention to it. Something's pushing out, making that smile spread and fill your body. But at the same time, something's pulling in, okay? That smile has an astringent quality. That smile arose from the same place as the visions and hallucinations. It was churned into existence by the same flow of impermanence right here and now. That was a self arising as a smile, arising as a laugh. All enlightenment means is to understand where your laugh comes from, which is, as I say, the self of that moment. Take a couple minutes if anybody has any questions that they would like to ask about this. Yes? Yeah, you were talking about shamanism as being sort of that intermediate place between going into the content or going straight down. I'm just wondering if you'd comment a little bit more on that. That implies it isn't an either or situation. I guess I'm wondering if you'd comment on whether there's some psychological value on becoming aware or involved to a certain degree. In content, yeah, that's right. Does that really take away from the going toward the source, you know, that's my question. Being involved in the content can help purify consciousness, but it won't bring about the radical purification that takes place when you observe how this material is churned into existence. But being involved in the content can help you, so maybe the metaphor is not a perfect one. There's an ambiguity in the word involved in content, so that's what needs to be clarified. There's two senses of being involved in content. One you can be involved in content in the sense you've got cravings and aversions, and that moves you out horizontally. A second way you can be involved in content in the sense that you are, like the entity talks to you and gives you spiritual wisdom. That's content, but it's useful to you. So that's helping you get closer to the source. Does that make sense? Yeah, sure. So being involved in content in the sense of, you know, I once was thinking of getting t-shirts made that said, my entity is older than your entity. It's like, that's getting involved in content in the sense of craving and aversion. It's like, I've got an exclusive on this particular kind of thing. So what tends to happen though is very few people observe the process that churns the visionary material into existence. Once that visionary material arises, it gets so interesting to people, or it becomes so frightening to people, or seductive to people, that they don't really look where it comes from. And in that sense you get distracted out horizontally. But that intermediate realm is its own realm, and those archetypes talk, and they talk the language of that realm, and it has its own value. But it just shouldn't prevent you from also going to the source. I don't know if I answered your question. St. John of the Cross put it very interestingly. I'm using a metaphor of course going from surface downwards. You could just as well use a metaphor or a paradigm of going from the earth upwards, like descending or ascending. You can look at it either way. The early Jewish mystics were called Yoridim, which means those that descended. But in a lot of Christian mysticism it's looked upon as an ascent. Either one's okay. And St. John of the Cross talked about Subida del Monte Carmelo, the ascent of this mountain, Mount Carmel. And he said exactly what I was trying to say, but in being a poet, in a more poetic language, he said when you climb up this mountain, you should not stop along the path, either to be frightened by the wild beasts or to pick flowers. The original recording ended abruptly at this point.

segments.text: I wanted to talk with you today about a phenomenon that some people experience on their spiritual
path, and that's the phenomenon of visions and hallucinations.
Just to talk in a general sense about what to do with that kind of phenomenon and a sort
of overview of where that fits in spiritual growth.
As I'm sure you're all aware, there are many models or paradigms that we can use to describe
the process of a person's spiritual growth.
And one of them that I'd like to share with you, it's just one out of many possible ways
of looking at it, is that we can talk about a path that is a journey from surface consciousness
to the source of consciousness.
And in traversing this path from surface to source, we pass through intermediate realms.
Now what do I mean by surface consciousness?
Surface consciousness is what we might call ordinary consensual consciousness.
There's a separation.
I'm over here, I've got my car over there, I've got to get on the freeway and negotiate
to get here, etc., etc.
This is the ordinary world that we function in much of the time.
What do I mean by the source?
Well the source is actually not a thing.
The source is an activity.
It's a process.
But we can, for simplicity's sake, consider it if you have the surface of consciousness
here, the source of consciousness would be deep, deep down.
So we can talk about bringing qualities of clarity.
Instead of just looking across the surface of consciousness, we turn 90 degrees and begin
to infuse clarity down into the substance of consciousness.
And in doing that, we are sort of clarifying the intermediate realms between the surface
and this activity of the source.
So from this model or this perspective, we can talk about three layers, although that's
actually somewhat misleading because the source isn't a layer.
It's a movement rather than a thing.
But for simplicity's sake, you can consider three layers.
Surface or ordinary consensual experience, the source, and then that which is in between,
the intermediate layers.
In terms of traditional Buddhist vocabulary, the surface is called the nirmanakaya.
Kaya means body and nirmana means appearance, ordinary appearance.
The source is called dharmakaya, which means the body of the absolute, you might say.
And the intermediate realms are referred to as the sambhogakaya.
Now sambhoga is a word that we don't exactly have an English equivalent for, but I guess
if we had to find one, it would be archetype in the Jungian sense of the word archetype.
The intermediate realms, the intermediate experience is both the dwelling place of our
problems, our blockages, our impurities, the things that prevent the surface from touching
the source moment by moment.
But the intermediate realm is also a realm of special powers and unusual experiences.
Sambhoga actually in Sanskrit means like glory.
Some people, as they're in this process of going from surface to source, encounter various
manifestations in those intermediate realms.
Special situations that can bring about those kinds of manifestations are sensory deprivation,
physical extremes like going without sleep, hunger, thirst, extreme cold, extreme heat,
physical pain can thrust one into those realms, as well as of course various substances that
people take.
In those intermediate realms, we can have actual experiences of encountering the archetypes.
Now in the Jungian sense of archetypes, archetypes are manifestations.
They could be manifestations of our impurities.
You can have things that come up for you that are very fearful.
You can see monsters, you can see ghosts, you can see terrifying manifestations.
Or you can see things that are very seductive, erotic, sexual.
In fact the very avatar, the very embodiment of fear and lust can appear.
Those are archetypes in the sense of manifestations of our impurities, our blockages.
And people see the most incredible things sometimes.
They see totally demonic things, demonic, even demonic ceremonies going on or very violent
acts or you see skeletons or all sorts of weird stuff.
Or an image can come up for a person that is like the absolutely perfect sexual object
for you, tailor made by the universe that you could never find in the physical world
ever.
Okay.
The girl or man or whatever fetish of your dreams, whatever it may be, that can never
actually exist can appear for you before your very eyes.
Of course the embodiments that happen in those realms are not just embodiments of the impurities
of consciousness, our craving and aversions, but can be embodiments of positive aspects
of consciousness.
You can encounter sages and saints and the positive spiritual archetypes.
That's why that realm is referred to as the Sambhogakaya.
In the positive sense one can see bodies of glory, beautiful bodhisattvas, buddhas, whatever
gods, goddesses, entities that can communicate with you, share things with you, help you
in the parlance of Native North America spirits.
Those intermediate realms can be quite interesting or they can be quite frightening.
What to make of these experiences?
In the title of today's talk I said using visions and hallucinations.
Vision sounds positive and in fact the Native North Americans talk about going on a vision
quest.
Hallucination sounds negative and false.
What's the difference between a vision and a hallucination?
I would suggest to you that the difference between a vision and a hallucination is what
one makes of it.
And it's not in my purview to comment on the ontological reality of these things.
In other words, do they really exist or not exist?
That to me is sort of a mute point.
The important thing is some people experience it and therefore it is a phenomenon that comes
up and needs to be understood and dealt with.
I know that the burning issue for a lot of people is, you know, is there an objective
spirit world?
Are these archetypes objectively real?
But that's something that I don't really address.
That's not an issue for me.
The issue is how does one relate to it in terms of really getting spiritual growth?
And what I'd like to suggest to you is that there are three ways of relating to the visions
and hallucinations that a person may have.
One way is that you can become interested in the content.
By that I mean, let's say that you give a positive vision, an entity, a spirit, a bodhisattva
appears in front of you and blesses you and you feel like energy and light coming from
this being and it's blessing you and purifying you.
Or maybe they'll speak words and those are words of wisdom.
So there's a positive content there and some people use that as a spiritual guidance.
By the way, I should mention, even though we use the word vision, I just want to add
something parenthetically that I left out.
These manifestations can take place in any of the six consciousnesses.
According to the Buddhist theory of consciousness, there are six sense doors, hearing, seeing,
smelling, tasting, the touch sense or the feeling body, and the thinking mind.
These are the six ways that consciousness manifests.
And although one often sees, and I guess that's why it's called vision or visionary material,
one can also hear, but one can also feel, actual touch and smell and taste.
It can happen in any or all of the sense gates.
I remember I once actually had an experience of, this was many, many years ago, it was
auditory, tactile and visual at the same time.
I had a hallucination that there was a little man tap dancing on my hand.
And not only could I hear his drum and see him quite vividly, but I could feel his little
feet touching.
So there was a tactile component there.
So so-called visions or so-called hallucinations can take place in any of the sense realms
and in all of them.
As I said, there are three ways that we can relate to this material.
One of them is in terms of content.
If the visions and hallucinations are on the positive side, if we're seeing saints and
sages and ancestors and spirits, people get information from this that may be useful for
them, inner guide type experiences.
Of course, if the visions and hallucinations are negative and we relate to it in terms
of its content, that means we get freaked out.
If they happen to be erotic and embodiments of our cravings, we get sucked in.
And it's sort of like glorified sexual fantasy, but really it's like sexual fantasy to the
max because it's like absolutely perfect and real.
That's getting sucked into the content of negative stuff.
Or if it's terrifying, frightening, bizarre, then we get freaked out.
Hopefully, a person will understand that in addition to being involved in the content
of what's manifesting, there are two other important things, ways to relate to visionary
or hallucinatory material.
Regardless of what the source is, whatever is causing it, be it drugs, be it sensory
deprivation, be it extreme pain, be it fever or illness, it makes no difference, whatever
causes it.
The two other ways of relating are in terms of purification and insight.
I guess I would rather say deep purification and deep insight.
As I mentioned, there are many models, many paradigms, many ways of describing how the
spiritual path works.
And one of the ones that I like the most is the one that's used in vipassana, the vipassana
form of meditation.
And in this model, one relates to experience, any experience, with two qualities.
One of the qualities is called mindfulness, which means a kind of precision moment by
moment about what's going on.
A second quality is called equanimity, which means literally in Latin, equanimous, means
a balanced consciousness.
But in this case it means an attitude of a witness state where there's not a pushing
away or a grabbing on.
Whenever one brings the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity to an experience, whether that
experience is intense or banal, whether it's ordinary or extraordinary, two things are
happening.
There is a process of insight and a process of purification.
What do we mean by purification?
Well, let's talk about what we mean by the opposite of purification.
The opposite of purification is, quote, impurity.
I always like to put the word impurity in quotes because the impurities are things like
craving and aversion, but also the negative tapes, the negative conditionings, the internal
conflicts.
You can use a lot of models for talking about the impurities.
You can use a psychological model.
We're talking about complexes.
We're talking about negative conditionings that a person has gone through.
We're talking about the tendency to inner conflict at all the different layers, including
a microscopic moment by moment, teeny frictions that arise in each of the six senses.
That's one way to look at the impurities.
Another way to look at the impurities is more of a theological model.
It's what in the West is called sinfulness, that which separates us from God.
Or another way to look at the impurities is that it is our moment by moment tendency to
congeal the flow of nature and freeze it into a thing called the self and a thing called
the world.
There's lots of ways to look at the so-called impurities.
The Buddhist parlance, the impurities, come under three basic categories.
Craving, which is the congealing or holding around the flow of pleasure, and the drive
to repeat pleasure, as opposed to simply the full experience of pleasure.
Aversion, which is the resistance to physical and psychological discomfort.
And then unconsciousness, ignorance, just not being aware moment by moment, or being
subject to processes that one is not aware of.
These are the three, big three, raga, dvesha, moha, the craving, the aversion, and the unconsciousness.
In any event, whenever one takes any aspect of experience, something as ordinary as your
clothes touching your body, something as ordinary as driving your car, or something as extraordinary
as monsters or saints appearing before your very eyes, whenever one takes any experience
and brings the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity to that experience, then insight
and purification is taking place.
In other words, blockages are being released and understandings are being fostered.
Now the kinds of understandings that we're talking about are deep understandings.
What do we mean by deep understandings?
Understandings about the fundamental issues.
In science they talk about fundamental research.
Fundamental research is hard, it takes a lot of energy, it takes a lot of time, it's expensive.
But when you get answers from fundamental research, thousands and thousands of specific
applications come out of one fundamental theoretical breakthrough.
In the same way, the thousands and thousands of solutions to life situations will arise
for you if you get one major breakthrough in terms of the fundamental issues.
What are fundamental issues?
Everybody in this room has a sense of self, don't you?
Don't you?
I certainly do.
I'm quite self-conscious as I'm sitting here.
If I were to start to point you out and mention your name and say things about you in front
of the group that we're either praising or condemning, wouldn't you have a rising of
a sense of self-consciousness?
We all have a sense of self.
Can you tell me something that's true and useful about that sense of self?
Fundamental insights would be things that are true and useful about how a person's sense
of self arises, where it comes from, what its nature is, and what is the relationship
between having a sense of an individual self and letting go of that identity and sharing
in larger identities or smaller identities.
What the heck do I mean by that?
Well maybe when you hear the sound of the horn out there, that's an identity that's
somewhat smaller than a human identity, isn't it?
Can you share in that identity and how can you do that?
How about the experience of this whole room here?
Or how about the experience of the whole universe?
Or the experience of another human being?
That's an experience that seems larger than an individual identity.
How can we share in that?
What's the relationship between our ordinary identity and the breaking of that ordinary
identity and experiencing other identities as ourself?
Can we have that experience?
And if we can, why do we have that experience?
What brings that about?
Individual understandings would allow us to understand something about our own individuality,
but also understand something about how to experience oneness with things.
How important is it to become free from suffering?
It's not a trick question.
How important is it?
Well you get the answer to that one the next time you suffer, either physically or psychologically
in any little way.
Correct?
You'll get the answer to that, how important it is.
It's more important than anything at that time.
Whatever a person's life may have been, once they start physically or emotionally suffering,
it doesn't mean beans.
There's only one thing that means anything at all, which is in that moment to be able
to be free from that suffering.
But what if the suffering arises from circumstances that can't be changed no matter what?
Is there still a way to be free?
Is there still a way to be okay?
Yeah, there is.
And to understand that, to understand that with crystal clarity is a very important insight.
So this is what we might call fundamental insight.
How about the experience of pleasure?
Usually pleasure doesn't bring permanent transformation.
All over the world in every culture, not in every culture, but in many, many cultures,
people are uneasy about sex.
It's the most intense pleasure.
Why are we uneasy about it?
Why do we look upon it as dirty?
This may be a shocking answer to some people, may be very off-putting, so please listen
carefully to what I'm going to say.
The reason people look upon sex as dirty is because it is, for most people, very dirty.
There's nothing dirty about pleasure, of course.
Just like the stronger the pain, the more we resist it, and therefore the bigger the
suffering it turns into, the stronger the pleasure, the more we grasp onto it, and therefore
prevent it from really transforming consciousness.
So what happens is that most intense pleasure, which is the sexual pleasure, gets surrounded
by so much holding and craving that its promise is never realized.
The promise, of course, is the promise of real satisfaction, lasting fulfillment, transformative
satisfaction, the kind of satisfaction that transforms consciousness permanently.
That's the prospect that is held out, that is almost never realized, because of the inability
to have a complete experience of pleasure.
Understanding that pleasure plus equanimity yields lasting satisfaction, and understanding
that pain plus equanimity frees one from suffering, to really understand that, to really see that
directly, not just believe it, but to have experience of it at every level of one's being,
down to the microscopic flow of the nerves themselves.
This is fundamental insight.
So pleasure is important, pain is important, self is important, oneness is important, separateness
are important, important to understand.
Just as there are many facets to purification, there are many facets to insight also.
Whenever one takes any aspect of experience, from the extraordinary to the banal, from
the mild to the most intense, and brings the qualities of precision and openness, that
is to say mindfulness and equanimity, one is fostering this process of releasing the
blockages and clarifying one's spiritual insight.
But different aspects of experience bring purification and insight in different ways.
And the case in point is the aspect of experience called visions and hallucinations.
If a person is able to bring the qualities of mindfulness and equanimity while they're
having visionary or hallucinatory experiences, then they reach very, very deep down into
consciousness, and purify and get insight in very, very deep ways.
In the Zen tradition, the visions and hallucinations that happen to some people in their practice
are often referred to as makyo, M-A-K-Y-O.
Now that's an interesting word in the Japanese language.
Ma actually comes originally from Sanskrit.
It's an abbreviation of the Sanskrit word Mara.
And Mara means, does anybody know what Mara means in Sanskrit?
The devil?
The devil, yeah.
Mara is the Buddhist devil.
Literally, it's the same root as the English root mortal.
It's the killer.
The adversary, Diabolos, Satan, is Mara.
And then in Japanese, it gets abbreviated to Ma.
And kyo is another very interesting word in Japanese, because it means, literally it means
where you live, both in the subjective and objective sense.
Kyo is the scene, I guess if I had to translate it into English.
And it refers both to your internal scene, in other words, your state of consciousness,
and your external scene, where you're abiding.
Your abode is kyo.
So makyo literally means the abode of the devil, if we were to literally translate it
into English.
So it's obviously a pejorative term, a put-down term.
But on the other hand, Zen masters often are happy when their students start to experience
makyo, because they take it as a sign that the meditation is deepening.
You're going from the surface realm, and you're now in these intermediate power realms, where
you're getting these weird experiences.
Not everybody has hallucinatory and visionary experiences on the spiritual path.
Some people clarify the realms between surface and source without ever having these experiences
at all.
But other people have these experiences.
Why do they put it down?
Why do they call it makyo, saying that's the realm of the devil?
Because people have a strong tendency to get involved in the content of that experience
and not simply observe it with mindfulness and equanimity.
As I say, if your visionary material is positive, if you've got spirits and saints in front
of you, getting involved in the content of that can be helpful sometimes to your practice.
If they're giving you blessings and good energy and helping you along on your path.
But getting involved in the content, even if it's positive content, even if you've got
an inner guide that's giving you good advice, is still not going to let you realize the
full potential of that experience.
And the reason that they put it down and they say this is makyo, ma means the devil, but
actually devil in the Buddhist tradition means something that blocks or gets in the way of
deeper progress.
When a person is having visionary or hallucinatory material, they are at a crossroads, you might
say.
They can go one of two ways.
Either you get caught up in the content of that material.
If it's positive content, spiritual content, well, that's not so bad, but you're still
caught up in the content of it.
If it's negative content, you're going to get involved in, you're going to reinforce
the impurities.
But in either event, if one is involved in the content of one's visions or hallucinations,
one is missing a fantastic opportunity, because when you get visionary and hallucinatory material,
it's a sign that you're in the intermediate realms between surface and source.
It's a signpost that you're going towards the source.
And if you're able to maintain mindfulness and equanimity with respect to that material,
you can very quickly plummet the source and get insight and purification.
But what happens is, do you all know what a self-limiting mechanism is?
A self-limiting device, that thermostat over there is a perfect example of a self-limiting
device.
You turn on the heat, the room gets hotter and hotter and hotter, but as the room heats,
it moves the spring inside that thermostat.
And at a certain point, that spring has moved enough and the heat turns itself off, and
the room doesn't heat up anymore.
Otherwise the room would heat infinitely.
One of the greatest dangers on the spiritual path is that the spiritual path itself becomes
a self-limiting mechanism.
It's got built into itself something that stops its own progress.
So you start to plummet from surface to source, and this intermediate material arises.
And you get involved in the content of that intermediate material, and now you've turned
90 degrees.
You're not plummeting straight down anymore.
You turn 90 degrees, you're now exploring out horizontally.
And it's become a self-limiting mechanism because the component of motion towards the
source has been eliminated.
And of course there are three extremes and a whole bunch of in-between possibilities.
One extreme is you start to plummet, you encounter that material, and it's weird or frightening
or enticing, and you say, I don't want to have anything to do with this, this ain't
for me.
Okay, this is makyo, this is the realm of the devil, and I can't handle it.
So you pop right back up on the surface and you say, I ain't going down into consciousness
anymore.
That's one extreme reaction.
A lot of people have that, typically a fear reaction.
I can't handle this, this is too weird.
And you've gone halfway down and you get into that and you pop back up and you say, I want
to stay up here on the surface where I can breathe the air I'm used to.
That's one extreme reaction.
A second extreme reaction is you get 100% involved in content.
You turn 90 degrees and it's now either you're pursuing the hallucinations as embodiments
of craving and aversion, or you're pursuing the hallucinations and visions as embodiments
of a kind of intermediate spiritual wisdom, but you're still pursuing that.
A third extreme case is you keep your mindfulness and equanimity and no matter how compelling
the visions and hallucinations, you observe them the same way you'd observe your breath
or the touch of the clothes on your body, with that matter of fact precision.
And then you keep plummeting down, down, down, down, down.
The intermediate possibilities are you get somewhat involved in content, but also you
maintain some mindfulness and equanimity and you go at an oblique angle.
You still have a component of motion towards the source, but you also have a component
of motion out.
A component of your movement is out exploring the content, the specifics of those visions
and hallucinations.
That oblique thing, which is in between, you see what I'm talking about in terms of angles,
right?
You can either go 180 degrees the opposite direction.
You can continue your motion straight down.
You can turn 90 degrees or you can have these oblique angles.
The preferred Buddhist path is straight down.
A very common experience is you pop back up on the surface and you don't go down anymore.
Another common experience is turn 90 degrees and get involved in content.
When you're turned at something between 90 degrees and straight down, this is the religion
called shamanism that has both aspects of insight and purification, but also aspects
of exploring those realms in terms of the empowerments and the content and whatever.
If you are turned 90 degrees and you have no component of insight and purification,
you're not going closer to the source, but you're getting more and more interesting,
powerful, unusual, or perhaps demonic experiences, then this is the world of, what shall we call
it?
If it's on the negative side, it would really be called Satanism and that kind of thing.
If it's on the positive side, then it might be called spiritualism in the sense of just
the spiritual powers and only lip service is being given to real spiritual growth.
Then there's a lot of intermediate that goes on, I mean in between angles.
In tribal cultures, there's both purification insight, but also they're interested in the
content.
They want to talk to their ancestors and their spirits.
As I say, from the perspective of Buddhist practice, the reason that it's called makyo
and put down is that people will have a tendency to turn 90 degrees and get lost in that stuff.
But also the reason it's put down is that people lose this incredible opportunity for
really deep insight and purification because here's the interesting phenomenon.
If visionary or hallucinatory material arises and you're able to maintain equanimity and
mindfulness, the visions and hallucinations get more realistic, not less.
If you maintain more equanimity and more mindfulness, the visions and hallucinations get even more
realistic, not less.
Now what do I mean by mindfulness?
Let's say that you're sitting and meditating and your patron saint appears in front of
you.
Or it's like it's happened to me times where a bodhisattva will appear in front of you.
What is this experience in terms of consciousness?
Well you're seeing something, so that's seeing.
You're having mental reactions like, wow, this is pretty weird.
That's thinking.
And you've got all sorts of body sensations, perhaps fearful, perhaps pleasant, perhaps
tensions.
Your body's reacting.
If you get negative hallucinatory materials, if you see like real sexy images, okay, again
you're seeing and your mind's thinking, my God, that is the most incredibly enticing
perfect female form.
Your mind's thinking, in my case, those are the thoughts that would be arising.
And erotic sensation over your whole body.
So what's the content of this experience?
Okay, seeing, thinking, and feeling.
To be able to keep track, that's seeing, that's thinking, and that's feeling in the body,
is to have mindfulness.
And to watch that come and go is to have equanimity.
Now let's take the seeing part.
I'm looking out at any of you when I see you.
Do I just look straight at you or does my eye sort of wander over your body?
Okay.
Have you ever noticed your vision's constantly shifting, isn't it?
Since you came into this room, how many times did the angle of your vision shift?
Thousands.
Each one of those was a complete, separate arising of the visual sense.
Do you know how large your angle of central vision is?
Central vision is the clear vision as opposed to peripheral.
How big an angle do you think you can actually see?
30 degrees.
It's actually a couple degrees.
It's like an incredibly narrow corridor that you can actually see anything clearly.
Everything else is very fuzzy.
Is that where your attention is concentrated?
Yeah.
What happens is that the eye is constantly wandering over the visual field, and it patches
the image together, and you get the sense that there's this panorama in front, but actually
you're just going, ch-ch-ch-ch.
Same way if you've ever paid attention to your body sensations, you'll know that the
awareness floats around inside your body.
And those of you that have meditated paying attention to your body sensations know that
as you become aware of how attention is constantly shifting in the body, the sense of the body
gets softer and softer, and you start to get a sense that really the body is quite insubstantial,
and there's a wave-like rising and fading of sensation.
And each one of those waves is made of wavelets, and the wavelets are made up of tiny little
vibrations, and so there is like expansion and contraction of feeling, and that's all
your body really is.
Well, the same is true for the visual sense.
So if you're looking at one of these hallucinations or visions, and you're able to be aware each
time your eye shifts over it, you see the head, you see the hand, you see, okay, and
you're aware of each individual arising and passing of your thought reactions, and you're
aware of how your body is welling up and fading in reaction, now you've got even more mindfulness,
okay, and you just let that happen, so you have equanimity.
Well, what happens is, as you're doing that, amazingly, the visionary material becomes
more and more realistic, the more detached you become, until finally it simply becomes
real, absolutely real, in the sense that anything is real.
In other words, we have a sense that, like, you're looking at a real world here.
The visionary or so-called hallucinatory material can become that vivid.
And as I say, the really interesting thing is, the more detached you are, the more realistic
it becomes, and the more vivid it becomes, until it becomes completely vivid.
If you are able to maintain mindfulness and equanimity to the point where it becomes completely
real, then you gain tremendous insight into the nature of how consciousness produces appearances.
